abstract.text: A default implementation for views that draw their content using OpenGL ES.

inlineContent.text: The

class simplifies the effort required to create an OpenGL ES application by  directly managing a framebuffer object on your behalf; your application simply needs to draw into the framebuffer when the contents need to be updated.
To use this class in your application, create a new
object and provide it an OpenGL ES context. Then, modify the view’s
, and
properties to configure the format of the drawable’s framebuffer object. After this, the view automatically creates or updates the framebuffer object whenever the view must be redrawn. A
object uses the regular view drawing cycle for a
object, calling its
method whenever the contents of the view need to be updated. Before calling its
method, the view makes its
object the current OpenGL ES context and binds its framebuffer object to the OpenGL ES context as the target for rendering commands. Your application’s implementation of the

method should call one or more OpenGL ES functions to render an image into the framebuffer object. Then, the view resolves any multisampling that you may have enabled and delivers the finished results.

Your drawing method should only modify the contents of the framebuffer object. Never attempt to read the pixel information from the underlying framebuffer object, modify or dispose of the framebuffer object, or read its other properties by calling OpenGL ES functions. Instead, rely on the properties and methods provided by the
class.
The
class can be used in conjunction with a
object to create an animation rendering loop that redraws the contents of the view at a specified frame rate.
Typically, there is no need to subclass the
class. Instead, provide a delegate object to draw the view’s contents. See

abstract.text: An [`EAGLContext`](doc://com.apple.opengles/documentation/OpenGLES/EAGLContext) object manages an OpenGL ES *rendering context*—the state information, commands, and resources needed to draw using OpenGL ES. To execute OpenGL ES commands, you need a current rendering context.
An object that manages the content for a rectangular area on the screen.
Draws the view’s image within the passed-in rectangle.
Speed up OpenGL ES or OpenGL app development. Use math libraries, background texture loading, pre-created shader effects, and a standard view and view controller to implement your rendering loop.
A default implementation for views that draw their content using OpenGL ES.
Binds the underlying framebuffer object to OpenGL ES.
The OpenGL ES context used when drawing the view’s contents.
The view’s delegate.
Deletes the drawable object associated with the view.
Redraws the view’s contents immediately.
The format of the color renderbuffer.
The format of the depth renderbuffer
The height, in pixels, of the underlying framebuffer object.
The format of the multisampling buffer.
The format of the stencil renderbuffer.
The width, in pixels, of the underlying framebuffer object.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view responds to messages that invalidate the view’s contents.
Initializes a new view.
Draws the contents of the view and returns them as a new image object.
A view controller that manages an OpenGL ES rendering loop.
Rendering loop callback methods for use with a
object.
Drawing callback methods for use with a
object.
The format of the color renderbuffer.
The format of the depth renderbuffer.
The format of the multisampling buffer.
The format of the stencil renderbuffer.
An object that manages the content for a rectangular area on the screen.
Methods your app can implement to respond to layer-related events.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
Methods that associate a unique identifier with elements in your user interface.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the [`UIAppearance`](doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIAppearance) API.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that can make a custom object eligible to participate in UIKit Dynamics.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
Methods that provide details about how to display your custom content in the large content viewer.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A type that can be an anchor for a popover presentation controller.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
